Yes, John Calvin and Martin Luther did present views on the study of word meanings. They were both influential figures in the Protestant Reformation and their ideas had a significant impact on the development of Christian theology and the study of language.

Calvin's views on the study of word meanings can be seen in his biblical commentaries, where he emphasized the importance of understanding the historical and cultural context of biblical texts in order to accurately interpret their meaning. He also believed in the importance of studying the original Hebrew and Greek texts, and he wrote extensively on the topic of biblical exegesis. For example, in his commentary on Genesis, he discusses the meaning of the Hebrew word "bara" (to create), arguing that it implies a creation out of nothing and emphasizing the significance of this concept for Christian theology.

Luther, on the other hand, was known for his emphasis on the authority of scripture and his rejection of traditional interpretations that he saw as contrary to the teachings of the Bible. He believed that the Bible should be read and interpreted by individuals rather than relying on the authority of the church hierarchy. Luther's views on the study of word meanings can be seen in his translation of the Bible into German, where he sought to make the text accessible to the common people. He also wrote extensively on the topic of biblical interpretation, arguing that the meaning of a text should be understood in light of its overall message and in the context of the gospel.
